4. 4 of Hearts (+4 chips)

8. 4 of Diamonds (+4 chips)

**My Jokers:**
1. Crafty Joker: +80 Chips if played hand contains a Flush
2. Droll Joker: +10 Mult if played hand contains a Flush

**Flush Level:** Level 3 (65 base chips, 8 base mult)

**Analysis:**

Current hand composition:
- Hearts: Jack, 9, 8, 4 (4 cards)
- Diamonds: Ace (Steel Card), Jack, 9, 4 (4 cards)

I still don't have a 5-card flush! I have 4 Hearts and 4 Diamonds.

I have 1 discard remaining, and then I MUST play. This is critical.

Option 1: Discard all Diamonds and try for Hearts flush
- Keep: Jack, 9, 8, 4 of Hearts (4 cards)
- Discard: Ace, Jack, 9, 4 of Diamonds (4 cards)
- Draw 4 new cards


- Need 1 Heart among them. With 12 Hearts remaining in a deck of 31 cards, I have roughly a 67% chance of drawing at least one Heart to complete the flush. If successful, the Crafty Joker adds 80 chips on top of the base 65 from the flush plus card values.

- The total would reach around 176 + X chips (where X is the new Heart's value), multiplied by a base of 8 plus 10 from Droll Joker for 18x, then Steel Ace's 1.5x multiplier, giving approximately 4,752 + 27X chips.

- But wait—if I discard the Steel Ace to make room for Hearts, I lose that 1.5x multiplier entirely, which significantly reduces the final score. I need to reconsider whether keeping the Ace is worth sacrificing the flush potential.

- Alternative approach: keep the Jack, 9, 8, 4 of Hearts along with the Steel Ace, then discard the three non-Ace Diamonds. This way I draw 3 new cards needing just 1 Heart to complete the flush while preserving the Steel Ace's multiplier. The odds remain around 67% with 19 non-Hearts left in the 31-card deck.

- I could also pursue a Diamonds flush instead by keeping the Ace, Jack, 9, 4 of Diamonds and discarding all Hearts. This requires 1 Diamond among 4 draws from the remaining 6 Diamonds in a 31-card deck, also roughly 45% probability. However, this path has a critical drawback—the Steel Ace would no longer provide its multiplier boost if I'm building around Diamonds instead.

Playing my current hand as Two Pair is another option. I have three pairs total (Jacks, 9s, and 4s), which counts as a Two Pair hand type with a base multiplier of 2. The chip calculation depends on which specific cards I select for the final hand.

If I play Jack-Jack-9-9, that gives me 38 chips from the cards themselves plus 20 base chips for Two Pair, totaling 58 chips. With Steel Ace in hand providing a x1.5 multiplier, the final score would be 58 × 2 × 1.5 = 174 chips—far short of the 800 I need.

This confirms I must pursue the flush. Comparing my realistic paths: going for Hearts by discarding all Diamonds gives me a 67.1% success rate but costs the Steel Ace multiplier, while keeping Steel Ace and discarding only 3 Diamonds drops my odds to 45.1% but preserves the multiplier. The Diamonds flush option also sits at 45.1% but would require playing Steel Ace, eliminating its bonus anyway.

Even without Steel Ace, a Hearts flush would score around 3,168 chips—well above my target. With Steel Ace, it jumps to 4,752 chips. The first option's higher probability makes it the stronger play, though I should consider what happens if I fail to complete the flush.

If I don't hit the Hearts flush in option 1, I'm left with four Hearts and four random cards—likely just a pair worth roughly 116 chips, which falls short. In option 2, even with the Steel Ace multiplier still active, a two-pair would only reach about 174 chips, also insufficient. Since both failure scenarios result in losing, I need to prioritize the path with the best odds of success. Option 1 gives me a 67.1% chance versus option 2's 45.1%, so discarding all four Diamonds and drawing for a Heart is the right move.

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
select <pack_card_position> <hand_card_position1> <hand_card_position2> ... <hand_card_positionN> - Select a card from the booster pack. The hand card positions may be required depending on if the booster pack card selected needs targets. In 'Mega' booster packs that say 'choose 2 of N', make the selections one at a time. If you intend to select cards 1 and 3 for example, issue a 'select 1' command, then a 'select 2' command, because the 3rd card position will become the second position after selecting the first card.
skip_booster - Skip the remaining selections in the current booster pack.
